description: I have accrued a lot of experience in C#.
It was the first programming language I ever learned,
starting with event driven Windows Forms / .NET Framework.
Soon after I learned game programming using XNA and Monogame.
Then I started using it in Unity, which I have continued to do
for about 4 years, for hobbies, personal projects, and even acedemic
work.  I have, using Unity, used C# to program both 2D and 3D games, as well
as some various applications to help me with tasks, such as a small queue
application to keep track of students I helped in my TA positions. Additionally
I have also been using it a lot as I explore its other uses for different small projects,
including using it with .NET Core in web development with Blazor (particularly for this website), and returning to WinForms
to rewrite the template into simple base game code.
I have also accrued a lot of experience in Java, although perhaps not quite as much as C#.
The main areas I have used it in are through acedemic work and internship work.  I have used Java for homework and class projects
where I have done things such as written programs demonstrating algorithms and data structures, and adding features to the server side of
a full stack web application involving modifying RESTful API code.
In internship work I have used it to write applications in Android Studio that I would run on Android TV products through adb.  In these applications
I used Java for networking solutions, using Java features such as web sockets.
I have also been using C++ for while, gaining a lot of experience.  I have taken a lot of acedemic courses where c++ was
the language taught, and have now even been working as an assistant teacher for 3 years in courses teaching c++ along with
software development fundementals and bash.  I have additionally used it in my own time occasionally, such as using it to program
a small text based console flashcard application to help me study.
I have been using Linux terminals for almost 3 years, mostly for classes.  This is where I have done the majority of my
c++ programming using the text editor "nano".  I have also done a bit of programming in bash, and have, in some of my TA work, helped teacher
students bash commands (such as those for file creation and navigation) and bash programming.
I have used the Unity Game engine for at least 4 years using the C# programming language for both personal and class
projects and both 2D and 3D games.  I have participated in game jams
More recently gaining experience in this, but I am easily and quickly learning it.  I made this portfolio using it.
More recently gaining experience in this, but I am easily and quickly learning it.  I made this portfolio using it.
I used this programming language in some college courses where I worked with a team to edit web applications for the Front-End side.  Also used
it for parts of this website.
Since taking a college class focused on this subject and even titled after it, I have practiced it in some of my own projects as I think about how to design the code.

Using Java and a bit of XML, I did some Android Application development using Android Studio for Android TV products as a part of my research process during my Software Engineering Internship at DISH.

I have worked with game programming as part of my own hobbies and personal projects almost as long as I've learned to program in highschool.  I started with the XNA/Monogame framework where I did not use

a game engine and instead had to work only with code, programming the steps to write graphics to the screen myself.  I then, a little before college, switched to Unity, where I have since exerecised game programming
in not only my hobbies and personal projects, but also course work.

I have had a lot of experience in python (although not as much as C#, C++, or Java) mostly having to do with Machine Learning.  I have taken several Machine Learning courses at college, using Python on Jupyter Notebooks

to work with various Machine Learning models.  This continues on with the rest of my experience, where my use of Python has mostly been in college courses, such as a course in Algorithms where programming assignments were
all in python to try out various existing algorithms.

I have gained a bit of experiecne in this having taken several Machine Learning courses.  I used Python, Jupyter Notebooks, PyTorch, Pandas, and other tools to try out and better understand Machine Learning concepts such

as Neural Networks.  In both courses I had projects at the end of the term where I took various concepts and tools from the course for a purpose of my own.  In one such project I attempted to use reinforcement learning and a
neural network for a modified checkers game.  Unfortunately due to a lack of time and resources to train the model, I could not get very good results, but I still feel that the experience was useful
, where I had to think about the various processes to train the players in the checkers game and how reinforcement learning works.
